data.question: What are the provisions related to the constitution of the Internal Complaints Committee under Chapter II of The Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace Act?
data.ground_truth:
According to Chapter II of The Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace Act, the provisions related to the constitution of the Internal Complaints Committee are as follows: 

Section 4 states that every employer shall constitute an Internal Complaints Committee at each of its workplace, having at least three members, out of which not less than one-half shall be women, and not less than one-half shall be from amongst employees employed in the workplace. The committee shall include at least one person who has been a judge or has had ten years' experience in handling sexual harassment cases.

The act also provides for the term, qualifications, functions and powers of the members of the Internal Complaints Committee.

data.question: How should the Internal Complaints Committee be constituted according to Chapter II of The Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace?
data.ground_truth: According to Chapter II of The Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace Act, 2013, the Internal Complaints Committee (ICC) should be constituted as follows: 1. The ICC must consist of at least three members, out of which not less than half shall be women, and shall include an employee representative, an employer representative and a member who is a person known for her work in the area of women's welfare or social work. 2. The Chairperson of the ICC should preferably be a woman and should possess knowledge and expertise in the area of sexual harassment. 3. The term of office of the members of the ICC shall not exceed three years. 4. The employees of the establishment are not eligible for appointment as a member of the ICC.

data.question: What are the procedures for notifying the District Officer in the context of the Constitution of Local Complaints Committee for handling sexual harassment complaints at the workplace?
data.ground_truth:
To notify the District Officer under the context of the Constitution of Local Complaints Committee for handling sexual harassment complaints at the workplace, following are the procedures:

2. The application should include necessary details such as name and address of the employer, name and address of the establishment, number of employees, etc.

3. Upon receiving the application, the District Officer will constitute the Local Complaints Committee as per the provisions of Section 4 of the Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace (Prevention, Prohibition and Redressal) Act, 2013.

data.question: What are the procedures for handling a complaint of sexual harassment according to the Local Committee's rules, specifically focusing on the grant process, audit, action during pendency, inquiry report, punishment for false complaints, and determination of compensation?
data.ground_truth:
According to the Local Committee's rules for handling a complaint of sexual harassment under 'The Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace', the procedures are as follows:

1. Grant Process: A complaint can be made verbally or in writing to the Local Committee, which shall be acknowledged in writing.

2. Audit: The Local Committee shall ensure periodic audits of its functioning and recommendations for improvement.

3. Action during pendency: During the pendency of the inquiry, the respondent shall not be victimized or discriminated against and the complainant shall be protected from any unfair treatment.

4. Inquiry Report: Upon completion of the inquiry, a report shall be prepared by the Local Committee stating the findings and recommendations.

5. Punishment for false complaints: If it is found that a complaint was false or malicious, the complainant may be subject to disciplinary action, as may be prescribed by the employer.

6. Determination of compensation: If the inquiry report finds that sexual harassment has indeed occurred, the Local Committee shall determine the compensation payable to the victim.

7. False evidence: If false evidence is produced during the inquiry, the person producing such evidence may be subject to disciplinary action, as may be prescribed by the employer.

data.question: What are the procedures and consequences for handling a false or malicious complaint of sexual harassment at the workplace during the inquiry process?
data.ground_truth:
During the inquiry process for a false or malicious complaint of sexual harassment at the workplace, the following procedures and consequences may apply:

1. Action during pendency of inquiry (as per Chapter V, Section 12): The accused is given an opportunity to defend themselves. They may be asked to provide their version of events.

2. Inquiry report (as per Chapter V, Section 13): If it is found that the complaint is false or malicious, an inquiry report will be prepared detailing the findings.

3. Punishment for false or malicious complaint and false evidence (as per Chapter V, Section 14): The person who has made the false or malicious complaint can be penalized according to the company's disciplinary policy or the law. This could range from a warning to termination of employment.

4. Prohibition of publication or making known contents of complaint and inquiry proceedings (as per Chapter V, Section 16 and 17): The company is prohibited from publishing or making known the contents of the complaint and inquiry proceedings, to protect the privacy of all involved parties.

5. Determination of compensation (if applicable): If the complaint is found to be false or malicious, the person who made the complaint may also be liable to pay compensation to the person against whom the false complaint was made, for any damages caused.

data.question: What are the duties of an employer as per Chapter VI, Section 19 of the Act related to The Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace?
data.ground_truth:
As per Chapter VI, Section 19 of the Act related to The Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace, the duties of an employer include:
  1. Formulating an appropriate policy for preventing sexual harassment.
  2. Providing periodic training and awareness to all its employees about sexual harassment at the workplace.
  3. Designating a competent internal complaints committee.
  4. Deputing a member of the internal complaints committee as a resource person to provide assistance and advice to the aggrieved woman.
  5. Conducting an inquiry in accordance with the procedures laid down if an incident of sexual harassment is reported.
  6. Taking appropriate disciplinary action against the perpetrator of the act of sexual harassment, if found guilty.

data.question: What is the penalty for non-compliance with the provisions of The Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace (Prevention, Prohibition and Redressal) Act, 2013?
data.ground_truth: Under The Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace (Prevention, Prohibition and Redressal) Act, 2013, non-compliance with its provisions can result in severe penalties. These penalties are intended to discourage non-compliance and ensure a safe and harassment-free workplace for women.

data.question: What are the powers of the appropriate government under The Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace Act, 2013, specifically regarding rule-making, act not in derogation of any other law, and difficulty removal?
data.ground_truth: Under The Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace Act, 2013, the appropriate government has several powers. Firstly, as per Section 29, the government has the power to make rules for carrying out the provisions of this Act. This includes rules related to the composition of Internal Complaints Committee (ICC), procedures for inquiry, and penalties for sexual harassment. Secondly, as per Section 43(5), the Act does not in derogation of any other law. This means that the Act is not meant to override any existing laws that may provide more protection or benefits to women against sexual harassment. Lastly, as per Section 44, the government has the power to remove difficulties that may arise in giving effect to the provisions of this Act. This could include clarifying ambiguous provisions or providing guidance on how to implement the Act in practice.

data.question: What are the legal provisions and measures in place to protect women from sexual harassment at the workplace in India, and how are complaints of such harassment addressed and redressed?
data.ground_truth: In India, the legal provisions to protect women from sexual harassment at the workplace are primarily covered under the Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace (Prevention, Prohibition and Redressal) Act, 2013. This act defines sexual harassment and lays down guidelines for its prevention, prohibition, and redressal. The act applies to all establishments, both public and private, with a minimum of 10 employees. The Act provides for an Internal Complaints Committee (ICC) in every workplace to receive complaints of sexual harassment, investigate them, and take appropriate action. The ICC comprises of individuals who are impartial and not biased towards the accused or the complainant. Once a complaint is filed, the ICC is required to complete its investigation within 90 days. If the allegations are found to be true, the Act mandates suitable action, which may include warnings, penalties, or even termination of employment. The Act also provides for confidentiality of the complaint and the proceedings, to protect the complainant's privacy and dignity.

data.question: I am an Indian citizen and I have been experiencing sexual harassment at my workplace. According to the Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace (Prevention, Prohibition and Redressal) Act, 2013, what are my rights and what steps should I take to report this issue?
data.ground_truth: As an Indian citizen, according to the Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace (Prevention, Prohibition and Redressal) Act, 2013, your rights include a safe and harassment-free work environment. You have the right to file a complaint against sexual harassment, and the complaint process should be simple and accessible. The Act defines sexual harassment as unwelcome sexually determined behavior (whether directly or by implication) that creates or promotes an environment of hostility, humiliation, offence or fear of intimidation. The steps you should take to report this issue are as follows: 1. First, you should inform the Internal Complaints Committee (ICC) of your workplace about the incident. The ICC is a body mandated by the Act to look into complaints of sexual harassment. 2. If you are not satisfied with the response from the ICC, you can also file a complaint with the Local Complaints Committee (LCC) within three months of the date of the incident or three months from the date you became aware of the incident. 3. If you are unable to file a complaint yourself due to fear or intimidation, you can appoint a relative or friend to file the complaint on your behalf. 4. It is important to maintain a written record of all incidents of harassment and keep copies of any correspondence related to the complaint. 5. You should also consider seeking legal advice to ensure your rights are protected and to understand the process better.

data.question: I am an Indian citizen working in an establishment funded partially or fully by the State Government. I have heard about the notification issued on 9th December, 2013, regarding sexual harassment at the workplace. Can you explain the details of this notification and how it protects me as an employee?
data.ground_truth: The notification I'm referring to is titled 'The Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace' and was issued on 9th December, 2013. This notification was issued by the Ministry of Women and Child Development in India. The main purpose of this notification is to protect women from sexual harassment at their workplace. According to this notification, 'workplace' includes any establishment, organization, undertaking, enterprise, institution, establishment or association, whether public or private, sector, funded partially or fully by the State Government or the Central Government. As an Indian citizen working in such an establishment, this notification provides you with protection against sexual harassment at your workplace. The notification defines sexual harassment as any unwelcome sexually determined behavior (whether directly or by implication) which has the effect of creating an intimidating, hostile, degrading, humiliating or offensive environment. It also includes making sexually colored remarks, showing pornography or any other sexually explicit material, physical contact and advances, demand or request for sexual favors, etc. The notification also lays down the procedures for dealing with complaints of sexual harassment and the penalties for violating these provisions.

data.question: What are the regulations regarding sexual harassment at workplaces not covered under the provisions of the 2013 notification issued by the Central Government?

data.question: What are the definitions of 'Chairperson', 'District Officer', and 'domestic worker' in the context of The Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace Act?
data.ground_truth:
In the context of The Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace Act, the definitions are as follows:
- 'Chairperson' refers to the Chairperson of the Local Complaints Committee, which is nominated under sub-section (1) of section 7.
- 'District Officer' refers to any officer who is notified under section 5.
- 'Domestic worker' refers to a woman who is employed to do household work in any household for remuneration, whether in cash or kind, either directly or through any agency.

data.question: What is the definition of 'District Officer' and 'domestic worker' in the context of the Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace?
data.ground_truth: In the context of 'The Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace', a 'District Officer' refers to an officer notified under section 5 of the Act. This role is crucial in implementing and enforcing the provisions of the Act at the district level. On the other hand, a 'domestic worker' is a woman who is employed to do household work in any household for remuneration, whether in cash or kind, on a temporary, permanent, part-time, or full-time basis. However, it's important to note that a domestic worker does not include any member of the family of the employer.

data.question: What are the guidelines for defining an 'employee' in the context of sexual harassment at the workplace according to Indian law?
data.ground_truth: According to the Prevention of Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace (POSH) Act, 2013 in India, an 'employee' includes any woman or man employed on regular, temporary, or ad hoc basis at an establishment, whether in the public or private sector, or in the unorganized sector. This definition is not limited to full-time employees and also includes part-time, daily wage workers, as well as those employed directly or through an agent, including contractors. The Act defines a workplace as any premises or part of a premises, which is owned, used or possessed by an employer or under the control of an employer, and includes any place visited by the employee arising out of or during the course of employment.

data.ground_truth:
According to the Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace Act, an employer has several legal responsibilities towards preventing sexual harassment in the workplace. These responsibilities include:

1. Creating a workplace environment that is free from sexual harassment.

3. Providing information, training and education regarding the provisions of the Act to all employees, including contract workers, probationers, trainees, apprentices, etc.
4. Providing a mechanism for redressal of complaints and ensuring that no victim suffers any detriment as a result of making a complaint.
5. Regularly reviewing the functioning of the ICC and ensuring its effectiveness.

data.ground_truth: As an Indian citizen, if you have experienced sexual harassment at your workplace, you have the right to seek legal action under 'The Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace' act. This act applies to any department, organization, undertaking, establishment, enterprise, institution, office, branch or unit of the appropriate Government or a local authority. The head or such other officer as the appropriate Government or the local authority may specify in an order is responsible for preventing sexual harassment at your workplace. According to the act, sexual harassment includes making sexually colored remarks, showing pornography, making requests for sexual favors, physical contact and other unwelcome sexual advances, demanding or requesting sexual favors in implicit or explicit terms, creating hostile work environment, etc. If you have experienced any of these, you should report the incident to the Internal Complaints Committee (ICC) of your workplace within three months of the incident or within three months of the woman concerned knowing about the incident. The ICC is a body constituted by your employer to deal with such complaints. If your employer does not have an ICC, you can file a complaint with the local District Magistrate or the Sub-Divisional Magistrate. It is advisable to consult with a lawyer to understand your rights better and the legal process involved in filing a complaint.

data.question: What are the legal responsibilities of an employer in preventing and addressing sexual harassment at the workplace, as outlined in 'The Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace' law, considering both contractual obligations with employees under sub-clauses (i) and (ii), and the employment of domestic workers under sub-clause (iv)?
data.ground_truth:
As per 'The Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace' law, the legal responsibilities of an employer in preventing and addressing sexual harassment at the workplace are extensive. For contractual obligations with employees under sub-clauses (i) and (ii), the employer is required to:

1. Create a safe and secure working environment free from sexual harassment.
2. Formulate an Internal Complaints Committee (ICC) to address sexual harassment complaints.
3. Provide information, training, and awareness about sexual harassment to all employees.
4. Protect the complainant and the witness from victimization or retaliation.
5. Ensure prompt and impartial inquiry in case of a complaint.
6. Take appropriate action based on the findings of the inquiry.

For the employment of domestic workers under sub-clause (iv), the employer has similar obligations:

1. Provide a safe and secure working environment.
2. Inform the domestic worker about the employer's policies against sexual harassment.
3. Ensure that the domestic worker is not subjected to any form of sexual harassment.
4. Take prompt and appropriate action if sexual harassment is reported or observed.

data.question: What is the role and composition of an Internal Complaints Committee (Internal Committee) and a Local Complaints Committee (Local Committee) as per the Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace Act, and what are the roles of a Member, Presiding Officer, and rules prescribed under this Act?
data.ground_truth: As per the Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace Act, both Internal Complaints Committee (Internal Committee) and Local Complaints Committee (Local Committee) have significant roles in addressing sexual harassment issues. The Internal Committee is constituted under section 4 and its composition includes a Presiding Officer, not less than two Members who are women and at least one of whom has been a victim of sexual harassment, and not more than three other Members. The Local Committee, on the other hand, is constituted under section 6 and its composition includes a Presiding Officer and at least two Members who are women and preferably from amongst the employees of the employer. The roles of a Member include participating in the proceedings of the Committee and ensuring confidentiality. The Presiding Officer is responsible for conducting inquiries, maintaining records, and ensuring that the Committee functions properly. The rules prescribed under this Act outline the procedure for constituting the committees, the manner of conducting inquiries, and the rights of the parties involved.

data.question: I am an Indian citizen and I have experienced unwelcome physical, verbal, or non-verbal conduct of a sexual nature at my workplace. Can you provide legal advice on how to proceed under the 'The Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace' act?
data.ground_truth: As an Indian citizen, if you have experienced unwelcome physical, verbal, or non-verbal conduct of a sexual nature at your workplace, you have the right to take action under 'The Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace' Act, 2013. The Act defines 'sexual harassment' as any one or more of the following unwelcome acts or behavior, whether directly or by implication: (i) physical contact and advances; (ii) a demand or request for sexual favours; (iii) making sexually coloured remarks; (iv) showing pornography; or (v) any other unwelcome physical, verbal or non-verbal conduct of sexual nature. If you believe you have been subjected to sexual harassment, you should first report the incident to the Internal Complaints Committee (ICC) at your workplace. The ICC is a body established under the Act to address complaints of sexual harassment. You can submit your complaint in writing to the ICC, which must be investigated within 90 days of receiving the complaint. If the ICC finds that sexual harassment has occurred, it can take appropriate action against the harasser, which may include warning, suspension, or termination of employment. If you are not satisfied with the ICC's handling of your complaint, you can also file a complaint with the local police or the National Commission for Women (NCW). It is important to remember that you have the right to a safe and respectful workplace, and you should not suffer any retaliation for reporting sexual harassment.

data.question: I am an Indian citizen and I have experienced unwelcome physical, verbal or non-verbal conduct of a sexual nature in my workplace. Can you provide legal advice on what steps I should take according to the Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace Act?
data.ground_truth:
As an Indian citizen, if you have experienced unwelcome physical, verbal, or non-verbal conduct of a sexual nature in your workplace, you have the right to take legal action under the Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace Act. Here are the steps you should take:

1. Inform the Responsible Person: The Act requires every employer to appoint a Local Complaints Committee (LCC) or Internal Complaints Committee (ICC) to address sexual harassment complaints. The first step is to inform the responsible person (usually the head of the organization or the person in charge of the ICC) about the incident.

2. File a Complaint: If the responsible person fails to take appropriate action or if you're not satisfied with the response, you can file a complaint with the ICC. The complaint should be in writing and should include details of the incident, the date and time, and the names of the people involved.

3. Attend the Inquiry: The ICC will conduct an inquiry into your complaint. You are required to attend the inquiry and cooperate with the committee.

4. Appeal: If you're not satisfied with the decision of the ICC, you have the right to appeal to the Appellate Authority.

5. Legal Action: If the employer or the respondent fails to comply with the orders of the ICC or the Appellate Authority, you can file a criminal complaint under the Indian Penal Code or a civil suit for damages.

Remember, it's important to act promptly and seek legal advice if necessary. You have the right to a safe and harassment-free workplace, and the law is there to protect you.

It is essential for all employees to be aware of their rights and the procedures for reporting and addressing sexual harassment under this Act.

In the context of preventing and addressing sexual harassment at a private sector organization, as per the 'Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace (Prevention, Prohibition and Redressal) Act, 2013' in India, both the employer and the employee have certain legal rights and obligations.

Employer's obligations include:

data.ground_truth: As an Indian citizen working in a commercial organization, you are protected under 'The Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace' act. If you have been experiencing sexual harassment, the first step is to report the incident to your employer or the Internal Complaints Committee (ICC) as soon as possible. The act defines sexual harassment as any unwelcome sexually determined behavior (whether directly or by implication) that could affect the woman's dignity or create an intimidating, hostile or offensive environment for her. You have the right to file a complaint within three months from the date of incident or within three months from the date you become aware of the incident. The act also provides for confidentiality of the proceedings and protection against victimization of the complainant.

data.question: What are the specific workplaces or places visited by an employee that fall under the purview of the Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace act, and how should such incidents be addressed?
data.ground_truth: Under the Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace act, any place visited by an employee arising out of or during the course of employment falls under its purview. This includes traditional workplaces such as services or financial activities including production, supply, sale, distribution or service; hospitals or nursing homes; any sports institute, stadium, sports complex or competition or games venue. It also extends to non-traditional workplaces like homes where domestic help or other employees work. If an incident of sexual harassment occurs in any of these places, it should be addressed immediately. The employee should report the incident to the Internal Complaints Committee (ICC) or Local Complaints Committee (LCC) established in the workplace. The committee will then conduct an inquiry and take appropriate action against the harasser as per the provisions of the act.

data.question: Can you explain the rules and regulations regarding sexual harassment in the workplace, specifically in the context of sports complexes, stadiums, or competition venues, which may be used for training, sports, or other activities related thereto, as well as any places visited by employees during the course of their employment?
data.ground_truth: In the context of the 'Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace', the rules and regulations are governed by the Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace (Prevention, Prohibition and Redressal) Act, 2013 in India. This act applies to all workplaces, including sports complexes, stadiums, or competition venues, regardless of whether they are used for training, sports, or other activities related thereto. Any place visited by an employee arising out of or during the course of employment, including transportation provided by the employer for such journey, also falls under this act's purview. The act defines workplace as 'any place visited or worked by an employee during the course of employment, including transportation provided by the employer for undertaking such journey'. This includes places where the employee may be present during training, sports, or related activities, as well as during travel related to employment. The act aims to protect women from sexual harassment and provides a mechanism for redressal of such complaints.

data.question: Can I seek legal advice if I have experienced sexual harassment at an unorganized sector workplace, which I visited as part of my employment duties and included my dwelling place or house?
data.ground_truth: Yes, you can seek legal advice if you have experienced sexual harassment at an unorganized sector workplace, which you visited as part of your employment duties and included your dwelling place or house. The Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace (Prevention, Prohibition and Redressal) Act, 2013, applies to all workplaces, including the unorganized sector. The Act defines a workplace as 'any place visited or frequented by the employee arising out of or during the course of employment', which includes 'a dwelling place or a house' if it is used or utilized for work purposes. Therefore, if you have faced sexual harassment in such a workplace, you have the right to seek legal advice and take appropriate action under the Act.

data.question: I am an Indian citizen and I work in the 'unorganized sector'. Can you explain to me my rights and the measures to prevent sexual harassment at my workplace as per the law titled 'The Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace'?
data.ground_truth:
As an Indian citizen working in the 'unorganized sector', your rights and measures to prevent sexual harassment at your workplace are governed by 'The Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace' law. According to this law, no woman should be subjected to sexual harassment at her workplace. The law defines sexual harassment as any unwelcome sexually determined behavior (whether directly or by implication) that could affect the woman's dignity, or creates an intimidating, hostile, degrading, humiliating or offensive environment for her. Some measures to prevent sexual harassment at your workplace include:

1. Establishing an Internal Complaints Committee (ICC) to look into complaints of sexual harassment.
2. Providing awareness and sensitization programs on sexual harassment for all employees.
3. Encouraging a safe and respectful workplace culture.
4. Ensuring that appropriate action is taken against anyone found guilty of sexual harassment.

If you are subjected to sexual harassment, you can file a complaint with the ICC or directly with the Local Complaints Committee set up under this law.

data.question: Can you explain the legal grounds for an Indian employee to file a complaint against explicit or implied threats, interference with work, or creation of an intimidating or offensive work environment due to sexual harassment, as per Chapter II of the Constitution of Internal Complaints Committee?
data.ground_truth:
As per Chapter II of the Constitution of the Internal Complaints Committee, an Indian employee has the legal grounds to file a complaint against explicit or implied threats, interference with work, or the creation of an intimidating or offensive work environment due to sexual harassment. This can include the following:

1. An explicit or implied threat of detrimental treatment in her employment.
2. An implied or explicit threat about her present or future employment status.
3. Interference with her work or creating an intimidating, offensive, or hostile work environment for her.
4. Humiliating treatment likely to affect her health or safety.

This is in line with the Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace (Prevention, Prohibition and Redressal) Act, 2013, which defines sexual harassment and outlines the responsibilities of employers and the Internal Complaints Committee to address such issues.

data.question: What are the responsibilities of an employer in constituting an Internal Complaints Committee to prevent and address sexual harassment at the workplace as per Chapter II of The Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace?
data.ground_truth:
As per Chapter II of The Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace, the responsibilities of an employer in constituting an Internal Complaints Committee (ICC) to prevent and address sexual harassment at the workplace are as follows:

1. The employer shall constitute an ICC in every workplace employing more than 10 persons.
2. The ICC shall consist of at least three members, of which not less than half shall be women, and one of whom shall be a woman who has undergone an awareness program conducted by the National Commission for Women or the State Women's Commission, or has undergone training in handling sexual harassment complaints.
3. The ICC shall appoint a Presiding Officer, who shall be a woman, and possess the qualifications specified in sub-section (1) of section 4.
4. The employer shall ensure that the ICC is functional at all times and that it inquires into each complaint of sexual harassment within a period of not more than ninety days from the date of receipt of such complaint.
5. The employer shall ensure that the ICC maintains confidentiality of all matters under its consideration.
6. The employer shall also provide for an appropriate punishment or other action to be taken against the perpetrator of sexual harassment, as recommended by the ICC.

data.question: What are the steps an employer in India must follow to constitute an Internal Complaints Committee as per the rules against sexual harassment at the workplace?
data.ground_truth:
An employer in India must follow these steps to constitute an Internal Complaints Committee as per the rules against sexual harassment at the workplace (as per The Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace (Prevention, Prohibition and Redressal) Act, 2013):
1. By an order in writing, the employer shall constitute a Committee known as the 'Internal Complaints Committee'.
2. The Committee should consist of at least three members, with at least one-third of its members being women. The Presiding Officer should be a woman and should have experience in dealing with issues related to sexual harassment.
3. The Committee should include one member from among employees working in the organization who have been subject to sexual harassment and have undergone training on handling internal complaints.
4. The Committee should include one person who is a non-governmental organization or association committed to the cause of women or a person knowledgeable in the laws relating to women or a person knowledgeable about issues related to sexual harassment.
5. The members of the Internal Complaints Committee shall hold office for a term of three years but they may be re-appointed.

data.question: What are the obligations of an employer in constituting an Internal Complaints Committee to address sexual harassment at the workplace, considering that the offices or administrative units may be located at different places or divisional levels?
data.ground_truth:
The obligations of an employer in constituting an Internal Complaints Committee to address sexual harassment at the workplace, considering that the offices or administrative units may be located at different places or divisional levels, are as follows:

1. By an order in writing, the employer shall constitute a Committee known as the 'Internal Complaints Committee' at all administrative units or offices where the offices or administrative units of the workplace are located at different places or divisional or sub-divisional levels.

2. The Internal Committee should consist of at least three members, with at least one-third of them being women, preferably from among employees or external members who are known for their work in the field of women's rights.

3. The Chairperson of the Internal Committee should be a woman and should preferably be of a rank senior to that of the complainant and respondent.

4. The Committee should have an expert member who is familiar with the issues relating to sexual harassment.

5. The term of office of the members of the Internal Committee should not exceed three years.

6. The members of the Internal Committee should be provided with training to deal with cases of sexual harassment.

data.question: I am an Indian citizen and I want to know about the provisions related to sexual harassment at workplaces where the Internal Committee has not been constituted due to having less than ten workers or if the complaint is against the employer himself, as per the amendments made under the Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace Act, 2013.
data.ground_truth: As per the amendments made under the Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace Act, 2013, if your establishment has less than ten workers, an Internal Committee for addressing sexual harassment complaints has not been constituted. Also, if the complaint is against the employer himself, the Internal Committee may not be able to handle the case due to potential conflicts of interest. In such cases, the Local Complaints Committee (now known as the District Level Committee) under the Act becomes responsible for addressing these complaints. data.question: What are the composition, tenure, and other terms and conditions for appointing members in a Local Committee as per the guidelines for preventing sexual harassment at the workplace in India?
data.ground_truth: As per the guidelines for preventing sexual harassment at the workplace in India, the Local Committee, where it is constituted, should consist of the following members: (1) A Chairperson, to be nominated from amongst eminent women in the field of social work and committed to the cause of women. (2) One Member to be nominated from amongst women employees of the establishment or association who have had experience in dealing with issues relating to sexual harassment. (3) One Member to be nominated by the employer and (4) One Member to be nominated by the employees or, if such employees so desire, through their association. The term of office of the Chairperson and Members of the Local Committee shall be three years or till they complete their term in any other committee, whichever is earlier. The Chairperson and Members may be reappointed for one more term of three years. The tenure of the members nominated by the District Officer can be for a period of one year or till the completion of the term of the Local Committee, whichever is earlier. The Chairperson or Member can be removed from office before the expiry of her term only on the grounds of misconduct or incapacity and after an inquiry conducted in accordance with the procedure prescribed by the employer.

data.question: Under the context of 'The Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace', what steps should the aggrieved woman take to settle the matter with the respondent through conciliation, ensuring no monetary settlement is made?
data.ground_truth:
In the context of 'The Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace', if an aggrieved woman wishes to settle the matter with the respondent through conciliation without any monetary settlement, she should follow these steps:

1. Firstly, she should approach the Internal Complaints Committee (ICC) or Local Complaints Committee (LCC) as per the establishment's policy.
2. She should express her desire for conciliation, and both parties should agree to participate in the conciliation process.
3. The ICC or LCC shall appoint a conciliator, who is impartial and competent, to facilitate the conciliation process.
4. The conciliator will then conduct a series of meetings with both parties to discuss and negotiate the terms of settlement.
5. If a settlement is reached, it should be in writing and signed by both parties.
6. The ICC or LCC shall record the settlement and forward it to the appropriate authorities.
7. It is important to note that the settlement should not include any monetary compensation.

The aim of conciliation is to achieve a mutually satisfactory outcome through dialogue and understanding, thereby avoiding further escalation of the matter.

data.question: What are the steps that the Internal Committee or Local Committee should follow when investigating a sexual harassment complaint against an employee, and what procedures should be followed in the absence of service rules applicable to the respondent? Also, what is the process for handling such complaints against a domestic worker?
data.ground_truth:
When investigating a sexual harassment complaint against an employee, the Internal Committee or Local Committee should follow these steps, as per the provisions of Section 10 of the Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace (Prevention, Prohibition and Redressal) Act, 2013:
  1. Record the complaint in writing.
  2. Inform the respondent about the complaint within a reasonable time and provide them an opportunity to respond.
  3. Conduct a fair, impartial, and confidential inquiry into the complaint.
  4. Give the parties involved an opportunity to present their case, call witnesses, and cross-examine each other.
  5. Prepare an inquiry report.

In the absence of service rules applicable to the respondent, the committee should proceed to make an inquiry into the complaint in such a manner as may be prescribed.

Regarding domestic workers, the Local Committee shall, if prescribed, investigate the complaint in accordance with the rules or regulations as notified by the appropriate Government or in the absence of such rules, in such manner as may be prescribed.

The process for handling such complaints includes initiating an inquiry, providing a fair hearing to both parties, and making a recommendation based on the findings of the inquiry. The recommendation can include disciplinary action against the respondent, if found guilty, and measures to prevent such harassment in the future.

data.ground_truth:
In the case of a prima facie sexual harassment complaint against a domestic worker, as per the provisions of The Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace, the Local Committee should follow these steps:

1. Immediately acknowledge receipt of the complaint.

4. The Local Committee should ensure confidentiality throughout the process and provide all necessary support to the complainant.

data.ground_truth: Under Section 509 of the Indian Penal Code (1860), insulting words, gestures, or acts intended to insult the modesty of a woman should be reported as soon as possible. However, within a period of seven days from the occurrence, you should report the case to the police for registration. This is in accordance with Section 154(3) of the Code of Criminal Procedure (CrPC), 1973, which mandates reporting of certain offenses within a specific timeframe. The relevant provisions include Section 509 of the IPC and Section 154(3) of the CrPC. In addition to this, Internal Committees or Local Committees under the Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace (Prevention, Prohibition and Redressal) Act, 2013, can also play a significant role in such situations. If you, as the aggrieved woman, inform these committees about the incident, they can initiate an internal inquiry and provide you with necessary support and assistance. It's important to note that reporting to these committees does not replace the legal process, but rather, they can provide additional support and protection while the case is being investigated and prosecuted by the police.

data.question: What are the steps that the Internal/Local Committee or the police should follow in case of a sexual harassment complaint, especially when both parties involved are employees?
data.ground_truth:
In case of a sexual harassment complaint where both parties involved are employees, the Internal/Local Committee or the police should follow the following steps:

1. The Internal Committee or the Local Committee should proceed to make an inquiry into the complaint. This inquiry should be conducted in a fair and unbiased manner.

2. Both parties should be given an opportunity to be heard during the course of the inquiry. This means that they should be allowed to present their side of the story.

3. A copy of the findings should be made available to both parties. This will enable them to understand the outcome of the inquiry.

4. If the Internal Committee or the Local Committee finds that sexual harassment has occurred, appropriate action should be taken. This could include warning the harasser, suspending or terminating their employment, or recommending disciplinary action.

5. If the Internal Committee or the Local Committee believes that criminal charges should be filed, they should forward the complaint to the police.

6. If the police receive a complaint of sexual harassment, they should conduct a thorough investigation. This should include interviewing both parties and any witnesses, gathering evidence, and determining whether a crime has been committed.

7. If the police find that a crime has been committed, they should file charges and proceed with a criminal prosecution.

data.question: How should an Indian citizen proceed if they are experiencing sexual harassment at their workplace according to the laws related to 'The Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace'?
data.ground_truth: If an Indian citizen is experiencing sexual harassment at their workplace, they should follow the procedures outlined in 'The Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace (Prevention, Prohibition and Redressal) Act, 2013'. The act mandates that every employer should constitute an Internal Complaints Committee (ICC) to look into complaints of sexual harassment. The aggrieved woman should first approach the ICC with her complaint in writing. If the ICC finds merit in the complaint, it will initiate an inquiry and provide a safe environment for the woman. If the respondent is found guilty, appropriate action will be taken, which may include warning, withholding promotion or transfer, or even termination of service. Furthermore, the employer is required to deduct from the salary of the respondent an amount considered appropriate to be paid to the aggrieved woman or her legal heirs as compensation.

data.ground_truth: Under the Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace Act, a complaint can be made under sub-section (1) if it is made by an aggrieved woman in relation to sexual harassment at workplace committed against her. On the other hand, a complaint can be made under sub-section (2) if it is made by any other woman who has witnessed the act of sexual harassment or is related to the victim. If the complainant is unable to substantiate the complaint or provide adequate proof, it does not necessarily mean that action will be taken against her. The Act specifically states that a mere inability to substantiate a complaint or provide adequate proof should not attract any action against the complainant.

data.question: What are the vice rules applicable for an Indian citizen in the context of reporting sexual harassment at the workplace, and under what circumstances would failure to substantiate a complaint not lead to action against the complainant? Also, how is malicious intent established in such a case?
data.ground_truth: In the context of The Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace, an Indian citizen is governed by the Vishaka guidelines and the Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace (Prevention, Prohibition and Redressal) Act, 2013. If a complaint of sexual harassment is made, the employer is obligated to initiate an inquiry under the Act. However, failure to substantiate a complaint or provide adequate proof does not necessarily lead to action against the complainant. This is because the Act specifically states that a mere inability to substantiate a complaint or provide adequate proof should not attract action against the complainant. Regarding malicious intent, it is established after an inquiry in accordance with the Act. Malicious intent can be proven if it is shown that the complaint was made with the intention to cause harm, damage, or distress to the accused without any substantial basis or truth in the allegations.

data.ground_truth:
In the context of The Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace, if the Internal Committee or the Local Committee finds that a witness has given false evidence or produced forged or misleading documents during the inquiry, they can recommend the following actions to the employer:

1. Disciplinary Action: They can recommend disciplinary action against the witness, which may include warning, suspension, or termination of service, depending on the gravity of the offense.

2. Initiate Legal Proceedings: If the falsification of evidence or production of forged documents is a criminal offense, they can recommend initiating legal proceedings against the witness.

3. Review of the Case: They may also recommend a review of the entire case to ensure that no injustice has been done to the parties involved, and to maintain the integrity of the inquiry process.

data.question: What are the measures required to ensure safety from harmful contacts at the workplace, display the penal consequences of sexual harassment, showcase the Internal Committee order, and organize regular awareness programs about the Act's provisions related to sexual harassment?
data.ground_truth:
To ensure safety from harmful contacts at the workplace and comply with The Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace Act, 2013, the following measures are required:

1. Safety Measures: Implement strict safety protocols and guidelines to prevent any form of harassment. This may include regular security checks, clear communication of workplace policies, and providing a safe and secure environment for all employees.

2. Display of Penal Consequences: Display the penal consequences of sexual harassment at any conspicuous place in the workplace. This could be in the form of posters, handouts, or email communications. The penalties include imprisonment up to three years or fine, or both, in case of first-time offenders. For repeat offenders, the imprisonment may extend up to five years.

3. Internal Committee: Display the order constituting the Internal Committee under sub-section (1) of section 4. The Internal Committee is responsible for looking into complaints of sexual harassment and taking necessary actions.

4. Regular Awareness Programs: Organize workshops and awareness programs at regular intervals to sensitize employees about the provisions of the Act. These programs should cover topics such as what constitutes sexual harassment, the rights of the victim, and the consequences of sexual harassment.

By implementing these measures, you can create a workplace that is safe, respectful, and compliant with the Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace Act, 2013.
data.title: The Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace

data.question: What are the consequences of sexual harassments in the context of the Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace Act, and how is an Internal Committee formed under this act? Additionally, what are the requirements for organizing workshops and awareness programs, as well as orientation programs for the members of the Internal Committee?
data.ground_truth: Under the Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace Act, sexual harassment at the workplace can lead to severe consequences such as disciplinary action, including termination of employment, demotion, or transfer of the harasser. The Act also provides for monetary relief to the victim. The Internal Committee, formed under this act, plays a crucial role in handling complaints of sexual harassment. It is constituted under sub-section (1) of section 4 of the Act, and it consists of at least three members, including a woman employee preferably with experience in dealing with sexual harassment issues. The Chairperson of the committee should also be a woman who has worked at a senior level in the organization. The Act mandates that the Internal Committee should organize workshops and awareness programs at regular intervals to sensitize employees about the provisions of the Act. Additionally, orientation programs are required for the members of the Internal Committee in the manner as may be prescribed. These programs aim to equip them with the necessary skills and knowledge to effectively handle complaints of sexual harassment.
data.title: The Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace

data.question: What are the obligations of an employer under the Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace Act in regards to conducting regular sensitivity programs for employees, orienting the Internal Committee members, and providing necessary facilities for the Internal Committee or Local Committee to handle complaints and conduct inquiries?
data.ground_truth: According to the Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace Act, an employer has several obligations in this regard. Firstly, they are required to conduct regular sensitivity programs for employees at regular intervals to sensitize them with the provisions of the Act. Secondly, they need to orient the Internal Committee members as prescribed. Thirdly, they are required to provide necessary facilities to the Internal Committee or the Local Committee, as the case may be, for dealing with the complaint and conducting an inquiry. These facilities could include providing adequate resources, support, and a conducive environment for the committee to function effectively.

data.question: How can I seek assistance in ensuring the attendance of the respondent and witnesses before the Internal Committee or Local Committee in a case of sexual harassment at the workplace?
data.ground_truth:
To seek assistance in ensuring the attendance of the respondent and witnesses before the Internal Committee or Local Committee in a case of sexual harassment at the workplace, you can follow these steps:

1. Issue a legal notice: Draft a legal notice to the respondent and witnesses, stating the allegations and the date and time of the hearing before the Internal Committee or Local Committee.
2. File a complaint with the police: If the respondent or witnesses are not complying with the legal notice, you can file a complaint with the local police station under Section 186 of the Indian Penal Code, which deals with disobedience to an order duly promulgated by a public servant.
3. Approach the court: If the respondent or witnesses still fail to attend the hearing, you can approach the court and file a contempt of court petition against them.

It is essential to consult with an experienced Indian corporate lawyer to guide you through this process and ensure that you are following the correct legal procedures.

data.question: What are the obligations of an Indian citizen in relation to providing information and assisting a woman in filing a complaint under 'The Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace' as per sections 9(f) and 9(g) of the Act?
data.ground_truth: An Indian citizen has certain obligations under 'The Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace' Act, specifically sections 9(f) and 9(g). According to section 9(f), if a complaint is made under sub-section (1) of section 9, the citizen is required to make available such information as may be required by the Internal Committee or the Local Committee, as the case may be. This could include any relevant information related to the complaint. Additionally, under section 9(g), the citizen is obligated to provide assistance to the woman if she chooses to file a complaint. This could involve helping her gather evidence, preparing statements, or simply providing emotional support.

data.question: In a scenario where sexual harassment has occurred outside the workplace, involving a non-employee, what legal steps can be taken under the Indian Penal Code or any other relevant law to address this issue, if the aggrieved woman wishes to take action?
data.ground_truth: In a scenario where sexual harassment has occurred outside the workplace involving a non-employee, the aggrieved woman can take legal action under the Indian Penal Code (IPC) or other relevant laws. The IPC has several sections that address sexual offenses such as Section 354 (Assault or criminal force to woman with intent to outrage her modesty), Section 354A (Sexual harassment and punishment), Section 354B (Assault or use of criminal force to woman with intent to disrobe), Section 354C (Voyeurism), Section 354D (Stalking), among others. She can file a police complaint under these sections. Additionally, she can also file a complaint under the Protection of Women from Sexual Harassment at Workplace (Prevention, Prohibition and Redressal) Act, 2013, if the harasser has made unwelcome sexually determined behavior with intent to intimidate, humiliate or offend her or create an hostile work environment for her. However, the incident must have occurred in relation to or in the course of employment. It's recommended to consult with a legal professional for guidance tailored to the specific circumstances of the case.

data.question: As an Indian citizen, if a woman has experienced sexual harassment at her workplace by an individual who is not an employee, what are the options for the District Officer under Chapter VII: Duties and Powers, regarding treating this as misconduct and monitoring report submissions?
data.ground_truth:
In the given context and title, the District Officer has the following options when a woman has experienced sexual harassment at her workplace by an individual who is not an employee:

1. (i) The District Officer can treat sexual harassment as a misconduct under the service rules and initiate action for such misconduct. This would involve following the necessary procedures and ensuring that the perpetrator is held accountable for their actions.

2. (j) The District Officer can also monitor the timely submission of reports by the Internal Committee. This would involve ensuring that the committee is functioning correctly and that all necessary reports related to the incident of sexual harassment are submitted in a timely manner.

data.question: As an Indian citizen and a District Officer, how should you ensure that sexual harassment is treated as a misconduct under the service rules and initiate appropriate action, and also monitor the timely submission of reports by the Internal Committee in the context of The Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace?
data.ground_truth:
As an Indian citizen and a District Officer, your duties and powers in the context of The Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace include ensuring that sexual harassment is treated as a misconduct under the service rules and initiating appropriate action against the perpetrator. This can be done by:

1. Familiarizing yourself with the service rules that define sexual harassment as a misconduct.
2. Conducting regular inspections to verify if the workplace is following the guidelines to prevent sexual harassment.
3. Taking prompt action if you receive a complaint of sexual harassment. This includes initiating an inquiry, providing support to the victim, and ensuring that the accused is given a fair hearing.
4. Imposing penalties as per the service rules if the allegations are proven.

Regarding the timely submission of reports by the Internal Committee, as per chapter VII, duties and powers of District Officer, you are responsible for monitoring the timely submission of reports furnished by the Local Committee. This includes:

1. Regularly asking for status reports from the Internal Committee.
2. Ensuring that the reports are submitted within the stipulated time frame.
3. Taking necessary action if the reports are not submitted on time, such as issuing reminders or initiating disciplinary action against the committee members.
4. Reviewing the reports to ensure they are comprehensive and include all necessary information.

By following these steps, you can effectively ensure that sexual harassment is treated as a misconduct under the service rules and initiate appropriate action, and also monitor the timely submission of reports by the Internal Committee.

data.question: How should orientation and training programs be designed for the members of the Local Committee to effectively prevent and address sexual harassment at the workplace according to the provisions related to The Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace?
data.ground_truth:
The orientation and training programs for the members of the Local Committee should be designed with the aim of effectively preventing and addressing sexual harassment at the workplace, in line with the provisions related to The Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace. Here are some suggested components:

1. Understanding the Law: Members should be thoroughly familiarized with the Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace (Prevention, Prohibition and Redressal) Act, 2013 and the rules and regulations under it. This includes understanding the definitions of sexual harassment, the roles and responsibilities of the Local Committee, and the procedures for handling complaints.

2. Sensitization and Awareness: Members should be sensitized to the issue of sexual harassment and its impact on women in the workplace. This can be achieved through workshops, seminars, or training sessions that aim to challenge stereotypes, promote gender equality, and create a safe and respectful work environment.

3. Skills Development: Members should be equipped with the necessary skills to handle complaints effectively. This can include communication skills, conflict resolution skills, and understanding of investigation procedures.

4. Regular Updates: Members should be regularly updated on any changes or amendments to the law or regulations related to sexual harassment.

5. Practical Exercises: Members should participate in practical exercises, such as role-plays, to simulate situations where sexual harassment might occur and practice appropriate responses.

6. Feedback Mechanisms: Members should be encouraged to provide feedback on the effectiveness of the training programs and suggest improvements.

The above components should be customized to the specific needs and context of the organization to ensure that the orientation and training programs are effective in preventing and addressing sexual harassment.

data.question: Can a court consider the previous instances of misconduct while awarding punishment for a sexual harassment case, and what actions can the government or local authority take against an offender in terms of their business or activity licences or registrations?
data.ground_truth: In a sexual harassment case, yes, a court can consider previous instances of misconduct while awarding punishment. This is because the court aims to ensure justice and prevent recurrence of such behavior. As for actions taken by the government or local authority against an offender, they have the power to cancel, withdraw, or non-renewal of business or activity licenses or registrations. This is provided under section 27 of the Indian Penal Code, which states that 'no court shall take cognizance of any offence punishable under this Code unless there is a complaint made by a person aggrieved by the offence or by some person authorized by him in this behalf, or by the father or mother, or by the husband or wife, or by the guardian of a person who, being under the age of fifteen years, is a victim of the offence, or by any person who has a locus standi to complain of the offence.', and under other relevant laws and regulations.

data.question: How can the rules governing the Lokpal specify the fees or allowances for Members, nomination of members, fees or allowances for the Chairperson, and other related matters in the context of preventing and addressing sexual harassment at the workplace?
data.ground_truth:
The rules governing the Lokpal, in the context of preventing and addressing sexual harassment at the workplace, can specify the fees or allowances for Members and the Chairperson in the following ways:

  1. Fees or allowances for Members: Under sub-section (4) of section 4, the rules can specify the amount of fees or allowances to be paid to the Members.

  2. Nomination of Members: Clause (c) of sub-section (1) of section 7 allows for the nomination of members. The rules can provide guidelines for this process, including the criteria for nomination and the fees or allowances, if any, for the nominated members.

  3. Fees or allowances for the Chairperson: The rules can also specify the fees or allowances to be paid to the Chairperson, as mentioned under sub-section (4) of section 7.

  4. Other related matters: The rules can include provisions related to other matters, such as procedures for addressing sexual harassment complaints, training for Members and staff on sexual harassment prevention, and confidentiality measures to protect the identity of the complainant.

data.question: I am an Indian citizen and I want to understand the roles and responsibilities for different members in the context of handling complaints related to sexual harassment at the workplace, as mentioned in sub-sections (4) of section 4, nomination of members under clause (c) of sub-section (1) of section 7, fees or allowances for the Chairperson and Members under sub-section (4) of section 7, the person who can file a complaint under sub-section (2) of section 9, the procedure for inquiry under sub-section (1) of section 11, and the powers for making recommendations, as outlined in the Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace act.
data.ground_truth:
In the context of the Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace act, the roles and responsibilities for different members are as follows:

  1. Members appointed under sub-section (4) of section 4: These members are responsible for carrying out the functions of the Internal Complaints Committee (ICC). They include a woman member who has worked for a minimum of 10 years in employment, a person familiar with the laws relating to sexual harassment, and a member from any NGO or association committed to the cause of women or a person familiar with the issues pertaining to women.

  2. Nomination of members under clause (c) of sub-section (1) of section 7: Employers are responsible for nominating at least one-half of the total number of members of the ICC as women. They should ensure that members are from diverse backgrounds and have the necessary qualifications and experience.

  3. Fees or allowances for the Chairperson and Members under sub-section (4) of section 7: The Act does not specify any fees or allowances for the Chairperson and Members of the ICC. However, the employer may provide them with necessary facilities and reimbursement of expenses incurred during the discharge of their duties.

  4. The person who can file a complaint under sub-section (2) of section 9: Any woman employee or former employee or aggrieved person can file a complaint of sexual harassment against another employee, in writing, to the Internal Complaints Committee.

  5. The procedure for inquiry under sub-section (1) of section 11: The ICC should conduct an inquiry into the complaint within 90 days of its receipt. The complainant and the respondent should be given an opportunity to present their case.

  6. The powers for making recommendations: Upon completion of the inquiry, the ICC can recommend appropriate action, which may include warning, imposition of monetary penalty, suspension, or dismissal of the respondent. The employer should take appropriate action based on the ICC's recommendations.

data.question: What are the wances to be paid to the Chairperson and Members under sub-section (4) of section 7 in the context of The Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace? Also, who can make a complaint under sub-section (2) of section 9, how should an inquiry be conducted under sub-section (1) of section 11, what powers does the inquiry authority have under clause (c) of sub-section (2) of section 11, and what kind of relief can be recommended under clause (c) of sub-section (1) of section 12?
data.ground_truth: Under the Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace (Prevention, Prohibition and Redressal) Act, 2013, as per sub-section (4) of section 7, there are no specific wages or fees mentioned for the Chairperson and Members of the Internal Complaints Committee (ICC). However, they are entitled to be paid reasonable allowances for the time and expenses incurred by them in discharging their functions. As for the person who can make a complaint, it can be made by any aggrieved woman employee or in case of a person with a disability, a relative or friend, or any other person who has knowledge of the incident. The inquiry under sub-section (1) of section 11 should be conducted in a fair and just manner and as expeditiously as possible. The Inquiry Authority, under clause (c) of sub-section (2) of section 11, has the power to secure the attendance of witnesses, summon records, receive evidence on affidavit and require any document or material to be produced. Furthermore, the Inquiry Authority can also take assistance from any expert. The relief that can be recommended under clause (c) of sub-section (1) of section 12 includes reinstatement, promotion, compensation for loss of employment or wages, compensation for harassment and other relief as the Committee may consider just and appropriate.

data.question: What is the appropriate manner of filing an appeal under sub-section (1) of section 18, and how should appeals be handled when a complaint is taken under section 17 of The Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace Act?
data.ground_truth: Under The Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace Act, the appropriate manner of filing an appeal under sub-section (1) of section 18 is by making an application to the Appellate Authority within a period of 90 days from the date on which the order of the Local Complaints Committee is communicated to the aggrieved woman or the employer, whichever is later. This appeal should be in writing and should contain the grounds on which the appeal is made. Once an appeal is filed, it should be handled by the Appellate Authority, who shall after giving the parties an opportunity of being heard, pass such order as it thinks fit affirming, modifying or reversing the order of the Local Complaints Committee.
